description: Litres, the largest e-book and audiobook platform in Russia, deleted almost 4,500 books over concerns that they might violate the law prohibiting drug propaganda. The removed books accounted for around 0.5% of the platform’s entire catalogue.

Following inspections of Chitay-Gorod bookstores in Nalchik, Chita, and Ulyanovsk, police have demanded that The Left Hand of Darkness, a science fiction novel by Ursula K. Le Guin, be removed from the shelves. Although the authorities have not officially explained the reason behind the inspections, they are believed to be linked to the novel’s depiction of characters who can change their biological gender.

Ad Marginem Press, an independent publishing house that focuses on translated non-fiction works in philosophy, anthropology, and cultural theory was fined 800,000 rubles (around $10,000) for publishing and selling the Russian translation of Olivia Laing’s Everybody: A Book about Freedom, which allegedly contains “propaganda of non-traditional sexual relations.” The book has been withdrawn from the market.

The Papercuts newsletter, run by the StraightForward project, reported that Russia’s largest publisher has been using the Chinese-developed Qwen AI to review books intended for publication since August 5, identifying content at risk of violating Russian law. Such content has been described as including “promotion of non-traditional sexual relationships, transgenderism and gender change, narcotic and psychotropic substances, the child-free lifestyle, cruelty and violence, pedophilia, incitement to suicide, pornographic materials, and extremism.” According to Dozhd (Rain) TV, that publisher is Eksmo.

The Tamizdat Project, a nonprofit organization and a scholarship initiative dedicated to documenting and studying literary censorship in the Soviet Union and contemporary Russia, was declared a foreign agent by the Ministry of Justice.
Alexei Navalny's memoir Patriot was banned as extremist literature.

Falanster, an independent bookstore in Moscow, and its founder, Boris Kupriyanov, were fined 800,000 and 100,000 rubles respectively (approximately $10,000 and $1,200) for distributing books and comics allegedly containing “propaganda of non-traditional sexual relations.”

Samokat, an independent publisher specializing in children's literature, has circulated to bookstores a list of 23 titles that must be returned “in accordance with current legislature.” The list includes books on feminism and those featuring LGBTQ+ characters.
A list of 37 books has been circulated to bookstores, with instructions to either destroy or return them to the publishers. The list includes, for example, Žižek's Jokes by Slavoj Žižek.

Falanster, an independent bookstore in Moscow, and its founder, Boris Kupriyanov, were fined 80,000 and 40,000 rubles respectively (approximately $1,000 and $500) for alleged involvement in the activities of an “undesirable” organization. The charges were based on the sale of a used copy of On The Way To Magadan, a book authored by a Belarusian anarchist Ihar Alinevich and published with the support of the Anarchist Black Cross Federation, an organization that provides support to political prisoners and was designated undesirable in Russia in February 2024.

Following an inspection in April, Podpisnye Izdaniya (Subscription Editions), an independent bookstore in St. Petersburg, was fined 800,000 rubles (approximately $10,000) for selling, among others, books by Olivia Laing and Susan Sontag, which allegedly contained “propaganda of non-traditional sexual relations.”

Eksmo, one of Russia's two largest publishing houses, circulated to bookstores a list of 50 titles to be either destroyed or returned, including the Russian translation of Red Closet: The Hidden History of Gay Oppression in the USSR by historian Rustam Alexander, published by Individuum in 2024.

Eleven current and former affiliates of Eksmo, one of Russia's two largest publishing houses, and its imprints, Individuum and Popcorn Books, were detained in Moscow for allegedly “recruiting people to join the extremist LGBT movement” by selling books containing “LGBT propaganda.” Three of them, Dmitry Protopopov, Pavel Ivanov, and Artyom Vakhlyaev, have been placed under house arrest for “organising the activities of an extremist organisation” under article 282 of the Russian Criminal Code, an offense punishable by up to 12 years in prison. Around 1,000 copies were seized during the raids.
Law enforcement conducted a search at Karta Mira (World Map), an independent bookstore in Novosibirsk.

Alpina Publishers blacked out several paragraphs, which reportedly discussed same-sex relationships or gender transition, in the Russian translation of How to Be Authentic: Simone de Beauvoir and the Quest for Fulfillment by Skye Cleary.

Falanster, the oldest independent bookstore in Moscow, and its founder, Boris Kupriyanov, were cited for participating in the activities of an unspecified “undesirable” organization, an administrative offense under Russian law. The court hearing was scheduled for May 26, 2025.

Law enforcement conducted an inspection of Podpisnie Izdaniya (Subscription Editions), an independent bookstore in St. Petersburg. The bookstore was ordered to remove 48 titles from its shelves, including On Women by Susan Sontag published by Ad Marginem in 2024.
The publisher Individuum was banned from participating in Non/Fiction, a prominent Moscow-based book fair held from April 10 to 13.
Law enforcement seized books by Hannah Arendt and Walter Benjamin from Katarsis, an independent bookstore in Kaliningrad.

Law enforcement conducted an inspection of Falanster, one of Moscow’s most well-known independent bookstores. During the inspection, officers seized books by Hannah Arendt, Walter Benjamin, Michel Foucault, and Susan Sontag.

AST, one of Russia's two largest publishing houses, withdrew All the Light We Cannot See, a World War II novel by Anthony Doerr, from the market for mentioning sexual violence committed by the Red Army in Germany. The book had been reported to the authorities by a pro-government Telegram channel.

Eksmo, one of Russia's two largest publishing houses, withdrew Irena's Children by Tilar Mazzeo, a biography of a Polish social worker who helped smuggle Jewish children out of the Warsaw Ghetto, from the market. First translated into Russian in 2020 and reprinted in 2024, the book was accused of “spreading false information about the conduct of the USSR during World War II” by a pro-government Telegram channel with 16,000 subscribers. Since 2014, such accusations have been treated as a criminal offense under Russian law.

The independent publishers Boomkniga and Cherny Kvadrat (Black Square) were banned from participating in Non/Fiction, a prominent Moscow-based book fair held from December 5 to 8. Cherny Kvadrat was banned for exhibiting works by “anti-authoritarian authors”; no reasons were provided to Boomkniga.

The publishers Eksmo and AST, along with the printing house Pareto-Print, were each fined 4 million rubles (approximately $50,000) for “disseminating pornographic content involving minors” Legacy, a novel by Vladimir Sorokin. Earlier that year, Legacy had been withdrawn from the market by its publisher.
The Russian translation of The Russo-Ukrainian War by Harvard historian Serhii Plokhy was banned as extremist literature. The book was never published in Russia.

Roskomnadzor, the Russian internet censorship agency, requested that Freedom Letters, an independent exile publisher, remove three works from their website: Mouse by Ivan Filippov, a novel set in a post-apocalyptic Moscow; Springfield by Sergey Davydov, a novel about a queer relationship in provincial Russia; and Not the Last Words, a collection of final courtroom speeches by Russian political prisoners.

AST, one of Russia's two largest publishing houses, blacked out several pages in the Russian translation of Morire per le idee (To Die for Ideas), a biography of Paolo Pasolini by Roberto Carnero, citing the law on “LGBT propaganda” as the reason.

AST, one of Russia's two largest publishing houses, withdrew five books portraying queer relationships from the market for containing “LGBT propaganda.” These books included Giovanni's Room by James Baldwin (first published in Russian in 2004), A Home at the End of the World by Michael Cunningham (2005), A Little Life by Hanya Yanagihara (2017), The Song of Achilles by Madeline Miller (2020), and Legacy by Vladimir Sorokin (published in 2023). Following AST's lead, Eksmo withdrew Real Life by Brandon Taylor (2021).

A book festival organized by Polyandria, an independent publisher specializing in children's and young adult literature, and its imprint NoAge was cancelled in Kaliningrad after pro-government activists accused it of promoting authors from enemy countries.

AST, one of Russia's two largest publishing houses, Chitay-Gorod, the country's largest bookstore chain, and LitRes, a major online bookseller, suspended the printing and sale of all books by Russian writers Boris Akunin and Dmitry Bykov, both of whom have publicly condemned Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

Text messages sent to customers of Falanster, an independent bookstore in Moscow, mentioning End of Regime by Alexander Baunov, a study of political transitions in Spain, Portugal, and Greece in the late twentieth century, were censored by carriers. The messages were delivered only after the book title was removed.

Law enforcement initiated an administrative case against the independent publisher Popcorn Books (later that year purchased by Eksmo, one of Russia's two largest publishing houses) for spreading “LGBT propaganda.” In 2021, Popcorn Books published Summer in a Pioneer Tie, a best-selling queer young adult novel, which was used as a pretext for the adoption of the law on “LGBT propaganda” in the summer of 2022.

Summer in a Pioneer Tie by Katerina Silvanova and Elena Malisova, a best-selling queer young adult novel published by Popcorn Books in 2021, along with its sequel What the Swallow is Silent About, were withdrawn from the market by multiple bookstores and online platforms under the law on “LGBT propaganda.”

Bookmate, an electronic book subscription service, along with its CEO Andrew Baev and Head of Marketing Alexey Dokuchaev, was declared a foreign agent by the Ministry of Justice. At the moment, Dokuchaev was also the CEO of two Bookmate-affiliated publishers: Popcorn Books and Individuum. Both were later purchased by Eksmo, one of Russia’s two largest publishing houses.

The Russian translation of A Woman in Berlin by Marta Hillers, published in Russia by Totenburg in 2019, was banned as extremist literature. The diary, first published anonymously in English in 1954 and in 1959 in German, recounts the author’s experiences of sexual abuse by Soviet soldiers. The author's identity was not revealed until 2003, two years after Hillers' death.

Customs officers in St. Petersburg opened and seized an Amazon package with the book The Future is History: How Totalitarianism Reclaimed Russia by Masha Gessen, suspecting it might encourage extremism and terrorism. The seizure was justified under regulations of the Eurasian Economic Union, which ban the import of materials “containing information that may harm the political and economic interests of Union members.”
